Award.AwardTitle: Mapping Gender Inequality in STEM Cross-Nationally
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed research will use a comparative macro-structural framework, a geographic mapping
approach, and country level data to examine gender inequity in STEM opportunities in a global
context. The proposal will request support for an international collaboration with Luis Berneth Pena, a Columbian geographer at the Georg Simmel Center for Metropolitan Studies at Humboldt University
in Berlin, Germany. The intellectual merit of the proposed research derives from an interdisciplinary, international collaboration between an American sociologist and a Columbian geographer. The collaboration
will allow the integration of a comparative macro-structural framework of gender inequity
in STEM and a geographic mapping approach. The influence of geographically distributed economic
and socio-political structures on STEM equity outcomes has not been carefully examined and
has the potential for revealing critical gender patterns in STEM opportunity systems. The
merit of the research is based in part on an integration of sociological and geographic perspectives
in understanding gender inequity in STEM inequity that is spatially distributed and correlates
with larger macro structures.
The broader impact of the proposed research is substantial given growing international focus
on gender inequality. As a result of this focus, organizations such as the United Nations
have promoted measurement of gender inequalities across countries. Measurement is often limited
to general health, education, and labor market issues. Gender inequity in STEM is a major
component in creating and maintaining gender inequity worldwide. An examination of gender equity in STEM education and occupations across countries with diverse economic and socio-political characteristics will lend insights and solutions for resolving inequities in STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project on “Mapping Gender Inequality in STEM”
was funded by the National Science Foundation’s Catalyzing New International Collaborations program. The project involved a collaboration between a U.S. sociologist who studies gender and science in a cross-national context (Dr. Sandra Hanson) and a Columbian geographer who specializes in a geographic approach to the social sciences and is an expert in mapping software (Dr. Berneth Pena). The collaboration took place in May, 2015 at Humboldt University in Berlin where Dr. Berneth Pena is a visiting scholar.  Research on the development of all STEM (science,
technology, engineering, and math) talent is critical given the increased
demand for well-trained technical workers, scientists, and engineers. In a
global society the status and power of STEM occupations make their incumbents the new elite. Across the world STEM continues to be a male culture, making 50% of the talent based under-utilized. Additionally, there is considerable evidence that diversity in science creates better science. Thus, research that seeks to reduce inequality in STEM has considerable impact, especially given the economic cost to this inequality. The project has considerable intellectual merit since it combines the gender theories and conceptual frameworks on gender inequality in STEM from sociology with a geographic framework and mapping approach. The project involved gathering data on girl’s and women’s access to STEM at various points in the science pipeline. This data on gender differences in science scores, STEM majors, and STEM occupations was collected on all countries with available
data. Additionally, we collected data on the social, economic, and political factors that are hypothesized to affect girl’s and women’s access to STEM. A
multi-cultural, structural framework guided the research on issues involving
how to think about and measure inequality in STEM as well as the factors that
contribute to it. The research findings show considerable male advantage in
STEM at each point in the science pipeline whether it be science scores of 15
year old girls or presence of women in STEM occupations. Results do show
considerable variation in this inequality, however, with some countries doing
better than others. The countries with the best access for girls and women varied, depending on which stage in the science pipeline was examined. Factors that influenced the presence of girls and women in STEM also varied with the STEM outcome being examined. For example, GNP and presence of women in Parliament helped predict countries with more women in STEM occupations but not access to STEM earlier in the pipeline. The geographic mapping approach taken here was essential for revealing these patterns that often went against standard thinking about economic development and inequality. A major thesis of this collaboration between a sociologist and a geographer is that disadvantage in STEM is spatially located and a geographic perspective will contribute insights and solutions for resolving this inequity.
